explanation:
- OS_CHECK_PATHNAME (macro): This macro appears in the target function and may expand to control-flow (if/return/do-while) with its own controlling expression. Its expansion must be inspected to determine whether it introduces any invariant controlling expressions inside the target function.
- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro): Same rationale as above — it may expand to control statements that could violate the MISRA rule; the expansion must be reviewed.
- OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch (function/implementation): The value assigned to return_code comes directly from this call. To decide if the subsequent if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) controlling expression is invariant you must inspect whether this function can return varying values or is effectively constant for the given inputs.
- OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint (callback passed to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch): This callback affects the behavior/results of OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch. Its semantics may determine whether OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch can produce non-constant return values, so it must be considered when judging invariance of the if condition.
- OS_SUCCESS (constant/macro): The comparison in the if is against this constant. You need the actual value/definition to reason about whether the comparison could be invariant (for example, if OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch is defined to always return this value).
- OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl (function): Although called only when the if condition is true, its presence may be relevant to ensure there are no macro expansions or inline constructs in the target function that alter control flow; include to cross-check any inline/attribute effects.
- OS_ObjectIdRelease (function): Called inside the if block; include its declaration/inline definition in case it is a macro or contains control-flow constructs that were expanded into the target function (could affect the overall control-flow analysis).
- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL (constant/macro) and LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE (constant/macro): These parameters are passed into OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch; their values/definitions may affect search behavior and therefore the variability of the return_code. Include them to fully reason whether the if condition can be invariant.
